update.description:
Field computer: 

creates a network bridge that allows the team docker container to run inside the vpn, with ip 192.168.2.10.

This can be tested with the following AMIs:

```
Simulator
name: src-0.1.18a
id: ami-b1edcdd1

FC
name: src-fc-0.1.12b
id: ami-e6edcd86

```
update.title: Vpn bridge

content.raw: yep, tested with `nc` and `rostopic` using the new ip address and they work
content.html: yep, tested with nc and rostopic using the new ip address and they work

content.raw: Great, thanks!  Have you tested this in a new constellation? I ask just to double check if we can safely merge already.
content.html: Great, thanks! Have you tested this in a new constellation? I ask just to double check if we can safely merge already.

content.raw: Nice. I made a change in 7d6d1b5 to just set the FC host to be `192.168.2.8`. So once the container starts, it'll stick to that IP address. Other than that, everything works for me.
content.html: Nice. I made a change in 7d6d1b5 to just set the FC host to be 192.168.2.8. So once the container starts, it'll stick to that IP address. Other than that, everything works for me.

content.raw: great, thanks for figuring this out. Do you have another AMI you're using to test this?
content.html: great, thanks for figuring this out. Do you have another AMI you're using to test this?

content.raw:
Note: The docker network creation command failed for me when using `--ip-range=192.168.2.9/32` . I got the following error: 
`$ docker network create --driver=bridge --ip-range=192.168.2.9/32 --subnet=192.168.2.0/24 -o "com.docker.network.bridge.name=br0" vpn-br0`
`Error response from daemon: failed to allocate gateway (): invalid bit range [9, 9]`

So I ended up using `--ip-range=192.168.2.9/31` .  This works. It assigns a temporal ip 192.168.2.8 to the bridge.  

With this setup the docker container is not able to access the internet.  I think if we add `--gateway=192.168.2.9` to the docker network creation , then the container will be able to access internet.
content.html:
Note: The docker network creation command failed for me when using --ip-range=192.168.2.9/32 . I got the following error: $ docker network create --driver=bridge --ip-range=192.168.2.9/32 --subnet=192.168.2.0/24 -o "com.docker.network.bridge.name=br0" vpn-br0 Error response from daemon: failed to allocate gateway (): invalid bit range [9, 9]

So I ended up using --ip-range=192.168.2.9/31 . This works. It assigns a temporal ip 192.168.2.8 to the bridge.

With this setup the docker container is not able to access the internet. I think if we add --gateway=192.168.2.9 to the docker network creation , then the container will be able to access internet.

content.raw: this `--ip-range=192.168.2.9/31` makes the br0 start with ".8" IP and not conflict with sim IP. Later it is changed to ".9"
content.html: this --ip-range=192.168.2.9/31 makes the br0 start with ".8" IP and not conflict with sim IP. Later it is changed to ".9"

content.raw:
OK, latest changes make the trick.  The FC docker container (`team_container`) is now NOT able to access the internet (which is what we wanted, I think) .  
The br0 bridge starts with 192.168.2.8 ip which does not conflict with sim machine. Later, once the FC docker image is ready, it is changed to 192.168.2.9 ip (overriding the original IP of the tap0 interface).

Please let me know what you think about this approach
content.html:
OK, latest changes make the trick. The FC docker container (team_container) is now NOT able to access the internet (which is what we wanted, I think) .
The br0 bridge starts with 192.168.2.8 ip which does not conflict with sim machine. Later, once the FC docker image is ready, it is changed to 192.168.2.9 ip (overriding the original IP of the tap0 interface).

Please let me know what you think about this approach

content.raw:
Thanks @iche033 . I did some changes based on your findings. Please take a look again 


BTW, the field computer docker container (`team_container`) is able to access the internet. I was able to do `ping www.google.com` from inside the container. Is this a valid outcome ? Or it should not be able to do that ? 
(maybe this is related to the new --gateway parameter I used to set the .9 IP ).
content.html:
Thanks @iche033 . I did some changes based on your findings. Please take a look again

BTW, the field computer docker container (team_container) is able to access the internet. I was able to do ping www.google.com from inside the container. Is this a valid outcome ? Or it should not be able to do that ? (maybe this is related to the new --gateway parameter I used to set the .9 IP ).

content.raw: have not verified how this would affect the docker container IP address though..
content.html: have not verified how this would affect the docker container IP address though..

content.raw: mm I just looked into it a little. I think it's because of the docker network create cidr block that lets docker start from 192.168.2.1, see comment inline
content.html: mm I just looked into it a little. I think it's because of the docker network create cidr block that lets docker start from 192.168.2.1, see comment inline

content.raw: changing `--ip-range=192.168.2.10/24` to `--ip-range=192.168.2.9/32` sets `br0` to an IP address of 192.168.2.9 for me
content.html: changing --ip-range=192.168.2.10/24 to --ip-range=192.168.2.9/32 sets br0 to an IP address of 192.168.2.9 for me

content.raw:
Thanks Ian, good to know it worked for you ! 

Re 192.168.2.1 , That was exactly the problem I was having and the (I guess) reason I lost connectivity in the VPN . It seems that when you create the docker network it sets that IP to the OS bridge.  Now , thinking again, I wonder if that docker network creation isn't actually also creating the OS bridge too (and thus assigning that default ip). 

Then the other instructions were placed to explicitly set the ip back to 192.168.2.9 and solve the previous issue. 

Do you want me to do some more explorations or should we keep it this way ?
content.html:
Thanks Ian, good to know it worked for you !

Re 192.168.2.1 , That was exactly the problem I was having and the (I guess) reason I lost connectivity in the VPN . It seems that when you create the docker network it sets that IP to the OS bridge. Now , thinking again, I wonder if that docker network creation isn't actually also creating the OS bridge too (and thus assigning that default ip).

Then the other instructions were placed to explicitly set the ip back to 192.168.2.9 and solve the previous issue.

Do you want me to do some more explorations or should we keep it this way ?

content.raw: great, it works for me. Just one thing, I saw that when the field computer is first launched, `br0` is set to 192.168.2.1, conflicting with the sim IP address. Did you notice this? Once the FC docker container is started, `br0` is set to the correct ip address, 192.168.2.9`.
content.html: great, it works for me. Just one thing, I saw that when the field computer is first launched, br0 is set to 192.168.2.1, conflicting with the sim IP address. Did you notice this? Once the FC docker container is started, br0 is set to the correct ip address, 192.168.2.9`.
